snippet.textDisplay: Getting a charge point late at night may not be a problem, but what happens when you are taking your family away on a busy bank holiday weekend? Motorway services and charge stations would be backed up for hours. I know this is the future now but until battery capacity / mileage matches the range of petrol and charging becomes as quick and available as a fill-up it will struggle to attract the average Joe Public I suspect. All current e-car options are in the high end price bracket, great if you can splash 30-60 grand on a motor but what's on offer for young workers or single parents. I have a feeling that within a decade or so, personal transport will be a privilege of the high income  class and the rest of us will be queing at the bus stop. I also imagine that charging costs will increase a lot over time as providers try to recover growing infrastructure costs and the government tries to recoup lost petrol tax revenues. Automotive fuel duty is a big part of the UK revenue stream, will restrictions be placed on those who charge at home or exploit free energy like home solar installations. They are going to want there pence per mile somehow!  I wonder what the big picture will look like in 20 years. I'll be tucked up in my wooden box by then so I don't have to worry about that.

snippet.textDisplay: WLTP may be better than the old Euro standard, but it's still too optimistic.  The EPA standard can be a little optimistic too, but is closer to what you really see.  EPA for the Tesla, for example, is 20 miles less.  Good tests.  It was interesting to see how each handled a full "driven till dead" situation.
snippet.textOriginal: WLTP may be better than the old Euro standard, but it's still too optimistic.  The EPA standard can be a little optimistic too, but is closer to what you really see.  EPA for the Tesla, for example, is 20 miles less.  Good tests.  It was interesting to see how each handled a full "driven till dead" situation.

snippet.textDisplay:
Bunch of useless vehicles from A North America perspective. I drive a Honda Odyssey 1500 miles loaded one way south and with my honda motorcycle towed on a custom trailer. Even at 75. mph fuel fuel economy is great @ approx 25 mpg US or 3.8 L. These are expensive vehicles that you can't go anywhere in reliably. Even a daily commute to work is risky. So I like Honda's idea of hybrids vehicles for the immeadiate future especilazy in NA with long driving distances. Not against the technology but it just isn't there yet and its going to be a long time before it is. Price is a hugh factor and the masses can Not well afford the these high tech vehicles. Maybe theyre OK in EU and UK but they wont work in Russia, Australia or anywhere long diving driving distances are required.

Good test nevertheless but gasoline is still king for now on the NA side of the pond. And if my automoble battery dies, I can replace it anywhere on the NA continent day or night 7 - 24. Try to get one if these vehickes serviced even at a dealer, better be under warranty or your loaded as its cost prohivitive to repair a AA battery powered vehicle anywhere.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a decent test with interesting results, I’d liked to have seen the details on how far they travelled at 70mph before dropping out.
Also, the thing about range is, it depends on where you’re driving. The majority of people will not spend their day on a motorway - how about a range test just driving a round a town all day, maybe with a short period of some more open A roads to see if the range changes dramatically based on type of usage?
snippet.textOriginal:
This is a decent test with interesting results, I’d liked to have seen the details on how far they travelled at 70mph before dropping out.  
Also, the thing about range is, it depends on where you’re driving.  The majority of people will not spend their day on a motorway - how about a range test just driving a round a town all day, maybe with a short period of some more open A roads to see if the range changes dramatically based on type of usage?

snippet.textDisplay: carwow i woud like to note that WLTP range figure (what car manufactures must quote in EU) is estimate range and not clamed. because for example model 3. EU WLTP estimate is that 348 miles (or 560km) but in USA EPA estimate is 322 miles (518km) and china NEDC is 366 miles (590km), butTesla estimated range in the screen when car is full is only 309miles (498km). so my point whit that is insted of saying that car got X% from claimed you shoud have said it got X% from WLTP quoted range, but specialy you shoud't say it got X% from full WLTP range when you didnt start whit full battery. because tesla actualy got 81% from that WLTP range, because you did start at 95% what is 330 miles because in WLTP estimate 1% is 3,48 miles. and as side note you actualy did get 87% from cars own estimate what when full shows 11% less than EU mandate very misleading WLTP number.
snippet.textOriginal: carwow i woud like to note that WLTP range figure (what car manufactures must quote in EU) is estimate range and not clamed. because for example model 3. EU WLTP estimate is that 348 miles (or 560km) but in USA EPA estimate is 322 miles (518km) and china NEDC is 366 miles (590km), butTesla estimated range in the screen when car is full is only 309miles (498km). so my point whit that is insted of saying that car got X% from claimed you shoud have said it got X% from WLTP quoted range, but specialy you shoud't say it got X% from full WLTP range when you didnt start whit full battery. because tesla actualy got 81% from that WLTP range, because you did start at 95% what is 330 miles because in WLTP estimate 1% is 3,48 miles. and as side note you actualy did get 87% from cars own estimate what when full shows 11% less than EU mandate very misleading WLTP number.

snippet.textDisplay: Charging more than 80% is meant to be occassionaly only, as it degrades the battery very quickly. My 400hp 3.0 v6 will do 40 mpg at 70mph on nothing but motorway and 25mpg urban. Extrapolated out and coupled with only being able to charge to 80% to save the battery life, the actual real world range of EVs will be significantly less, probably IRO of 180miles for the Tesla.
snippet.textOriginal: Charging more than 80% is meant to be occassionaly only, as it degrades the battery very quickly. My 400hp 3.0 v6 will do 40 mpg at 70mph on nothing but motorway and 25mpg urban. snippet.textDisplay:
It would be nice if there was tests in winter temperatures like 0°C (32°F), -5°C (23°F), -10°C (14°F), -20°C (-4°F), -30°C (-22°F), -40°C (-40°F) for people living in areas where temperatures can be very low, because how good is it when those batteries refuse to release the stored energy or leave you with a 20% capacity when the battery is fully loaded and you actually also needs to use the heating elements and the fan, it's a risky thing to get out in an electric car in the winter so it is a very relevant task that can så e lifes.?
So please test or recommend some known sources with a good reputation and high reliability.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
So, put more 2-3 peoples on those cars, some luggage, consider is winter, you need AC, and you will get probably 50% or less from the "official" range;
What mean that: ANY old car, with diesel or gasoline engine, A LOT cheaper, will still do more than double km.s than you. Hell, I owned a fraking WW Golf, Diesel, 1600cc, who was able to do more than 1000km with a full tank ! And 3 peoples.
My opinion is, until we get a much better battery, the electric cars are just unable to compete. Not to comment they are absolutely useless in countries where the winter bring 10-20 Cº negative.
Turning on the heater at -10 C º will CUT the range at 41 % ! Just think at that....
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/06/aaa-confirms-what-tesla-bmw-nissan-ev-owners-suspected-of-cold-weather.html

snippet.textDisplay:
Re temperature - UK average of 10C in only when avergaed across the whole day and whole year. Relaitsically not that many journeys at 1am - 6am when coldest. Average peak during year daytime is 14C (20 in summer and 7 winter). The 7C you had here I think would classify this as reasonable test of range for an average UK winter - but not throughout year.
For daytime driving and throughout spring/summer/autumn you can add another 10 to 30miles onto the ranges achieved - here which would likely make them far more in line with claimed range.
snippet.textOriginal:
Re temperature - UK average of 10C in only when  avergaed across the whole day and whole year. Relaitsically not that many journeys at 1am - 6am when coldest. Average peak during year daytime is 14C   (20 in summer and 7 winter).  The 7C you had here I think would  classify this as reasonable test of range for an average UK winter  - but not throughout year. 
For daytime driving and throughout spring/summer/autumn you can add another 10 to 30miles onto the ranges achieved - here which would likely make them far more in line with claimed range.

snippet.textDisplay:
Electric cars should not be charged to 100% and left overnight because it shortens battery life. Tesla clearly tell you not do it unless you drive the car immediately. It’s also bad for the battery to run them flat.
We are now told it’s quicker overall to stop regularly and top up the charge rather than keep going and wait for a full charge to fill It.

snippet.textDisplay: 27:43 as a sat nav user since 1993 here in Germany (Philips Carin and VDO Dayton systems), I have always left it on since in doing so you continued (and still do) to receive TMC information (which also existed back then). It also always aided in correct speedo readings as radar traps here are mobile and unsuspecting with draconian fines. It also indicated real GPS measured speed which, as you will know, is a lot more accurate than the analogue speedo, especially at high speed.
snippet.textOriginal: 27:43 as a sat nav user since 1993 here in Germany (Philips Carin and VDO Dayton systems), I have always left it on since in doing so you continued (and still do) to receive TMC information (which also existed back then). It also always aided in correct speedo readings as radar traps here are mobile and unsuspecting with draconian fines. It also indicated real GPS measured speed which, as you will know, is a lot more accurate than the analogue speedo, especially at high speed.

snippet.textDisplay: Having owned 5 EV’s since 2013 from Nissan, BMW, Kia and now Tesla there is only 1 winner if you regularly do long trips and it’s a Tesla. Not because of the range alone but because of the extensive network of Supercharging that Tesla have built across the UK and Europe. And they are not sitting on their achievements either as they continue to add new locations at a great pace. I did a 400 mile journey last week with less that 1 hour of charging. Range anxiety is a thing of the past for me. In 7 years I’ve only been recovered once and that was in 2014 in a Leaf. I arrived at the motorway service station to find the charger out of service on both sides of the road (I used the service road to cross over). I then ran out of charge 7 miles later trying to get to the nearest charge point. The most range I’ve had between charges on my Model 3 is 305 in the summer @ an average of 55 mph and I had 5% left.
snippet.textOriginal: Having owned 5 EV’s since 2013 from Nissan, BMW, Kia and now Tesla there is only 1 winner if you regularly do long trips and it’s a Tesla. Not because of the range alone but because of the extensive network of Supercharging that Tesla have built across the UK and Europe. And they are not sitting on their achievements either as they continue to add new locations at a great pace. I did a 400 mile journey last week with less that 1 hour of charging. Range anxiety is a thing of the past for me. In 7 years I’ve only been recovered once and that was in 2014 in a Leaf. I arrived at the motorway service station to find the charger out of service on both sides of the road (I used the service road to cross over). I then ran out of charge 7 miles later trying to get to the nearest charge point. The most range I’ve had between charges on my Model 3 is 305 in the summer @ an average of 55 mph and I had 5% left.

snippet.textDisplay:
Imagine how worse the ranges would have been had the cars been full of passengers and luggage and hills to climb and if tyre pressures were lower than required, a frequently overlooked weekly mtce. issue. And don't forget that all batteries lose efficiency over time further reducing their stamina. For me, this excellent video shows the many anxieties involved in owning and driving an electric car given the current state of battery technology. Such cars maybe quick, silent and cheap to run but they're very expensive to buy and could plummet in second hand value as batteries will be viewed as a potentially huge expense to replace.
It's still far too early to invest in one of these cars IMHO. It's great that they're being developed but their range needs to be at least doubled, even trebled, to those seen in this video before anxieties are lessened. Imagine losing all power on any road or motorway with traffic barrelling along behind and I'll wager that we'll increasingly witness many electric vehicles stuck at roadsides awaiting recovery. Thanks for the video Car Wow but it's done nothing to persuade me that I want an electric car at this time. Jan 2020. Dave in Edinburgh.
snippet.textOriginal:
Imagine how worse the ranges would have been had the cars been full of passengers and luggage and hills to climb and if  tyre pressures were lower than required, a frequently overlooked weekly mtce. issue. And don't forget that all batteries lose efficiency over time further reducing their stamina. For me, this excellent video shows the many anxieties involved in owning and driving an electric car given the current state of battery technology. Such cars maybe quick, silent and cheap to run but they're very expensive to buy and could plummet in second hand value as batteries will be viewed as a potentially huge expense to replace.
It's still far too early to invest in one of these cars IMHO. It's great that they're being developed but their range needs to be at least doubled, even trebled, to those seen in this video before anxieties are lessened. Imagine losing all power on any road or motorway with traffic barrelling along behind and I'll wager that we'll increasingly witness many electric vehicles stuck at  roadsides awaiting recovery. Thanks for the video Car Wow but it's done nothing to persuade me that I want an electric car at this time. Jan 2020. Dave in Edinburgh.

snippet.textDisplay: Really enjoyed your test Matt and I think it is very worthwhile. If you find the time I’d love for you to do the same test in town. Of course it would take an agonizingly long time and would test everyone’s patience. But I suspect all of the vehicles would be much closer to their published range if all the driving were in slower, stop and go traffic. It would also be interesting to see who has engineered the best regeneration capability into their drivetrain. I suspect that ratings will eventually be offered for city and highway driving because I can, after owning two BMW i3s and now a Tesla Model 3, attest to the fact that electric car range is lower in steady highway driving than city driving.
snippet.textOriginal: Really enjoyed your test Matt and I think it is very worthwhile. If you find the time I’d love for you to do the same test in town. Of course it would take an agonizingly long time and would test everyone’s patience. But I suspect all of the vehicles would be much closer to their published range if all the driving were in slower, stop and go traffic. It would also be interesting to see who has engineered the best regeneration capability into their drivetrain. I suspect that ratings will eventually be offered for city and highway driving because I can, after owning two BMW i3s and now a Tesla Model 3, attest to the fact that electric car range is lower in steady highway driving than city driving.

All of these cars are absolutely useless were I live in Australia. I will drive to Sydney some 900 klms and takes about nine hours on a less than a full tank of diesel. To stop for a recharge would mean an overnight stay.
